body:
An example statistics for CP that might address @mboehm7 's concerns as well as make the instrumentation reusable :)

```
  2  leftIndex [268:4-268:17]                 43.341      86  aqrd[0.000s,172], rls[0.000s,172], lixcp[0.516s,86]
  3  leftIndex [108:4-108:42]                 31.743   66564  aqrd[23.509s,133128], lixcp[7.464s,66564], rls[0.073s,133128]
```

yes! @nakul02  There was a fix by another PR before this, which is otherwise responsible for previous build failure https://sparktc.ibmcloud.com/jenkins/job/SystemML-PullRequestBuilder/1777/ . Now, that test is passing in that particular test.

Before implementing svd as a builtin function, I would recommend to investigate if it could be implemented efficiently in dml or not. If yes, then I would prefer having a dml bodied function because then all other compilation and runtime techniques automatically apply. If it turns out that the dml version has performance or scalability issues, we can discuss to add a builtin function instead. In this case, we would need to break this endeavor into two steps of local and distributed operations. If you need this svd builtin immediately, you can workaround via a java-based external function that calls some local implementation.  

Just as a background: Yes, there are builtin functions like solve, inverse, qr, lu, and eigen which only have local operations (by calling out to commons math). These functions were added for convenience but are typically only applied on small data. However, the missing distributed operations are unsatisfying because they do not adhere to the overall philosophy of SystemML. Moving forward, we would like to either add distributed operators for these operations or replace them by dml scripts which would automatically be compiled to distributed operations.
FullReblockTest is one of our flaky tests which unfortunately fails once in a while.

@mboehm7  thanks for looking into this. Like `qr`, `lu`, and `eigen` we try to implement a local `svd( )` function which is helpful for the development of scalable `svd( )` in dml as we have done for `qr`, `lu` 
 in this directory https://github.com/j143/systemml/tree/master/scripts/staging/scalable_linalg .
I understand - are you saying you cannot implement svd in dml efficiently?

I tried out the `systemml.stats.finegrained`, and IMO, this looks very useful, especially for contributors such as myself who have limited profiling experience with the project. I believe I will use this a lot. Thank you @niketanpansare. LGTM.

@niketanpansare @nakul02 Would it be possible to allow this to be turned on via MLContext and DMLScript?
Ideally yes via `setConfigProperty`, but I can double-check :)

I think yes. But, I am following the instructions in this [jira](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/SYSTEMML-1214). 
If you feel that we should implement scalable `svd( )` in dml w/o a local built-in, we can try that.

thanks @j143 - yes, as mentioned above, I think we should first give a basic dml implementation as try and only resort to a builtin function if the dml implementation has fundamental issues in terms of performance or scalability.
@j143 @nakul02 Note that it is possible to manually trigger a Jenkins PR test (if ever needed). See https://gist.github.com/deroneriksson/e0d6d0634f3388f0df5e#pull-request-magic for the command.

Please remember to consider the case when the left index is inside a parfor and you have a mutiple GPU configuration. There could be coherency issues.

@deroneriksson - is there a way to disable it?

This PR introduces a set of python scripts which are never invoked directly or indirectly in anything that Jenkins does. Running the tests over and over again for each commit seems wasteful. It would be good to be able to disable the automatic running of the jenkins for every commit.
I don't know if there's a way to disable it. There are situations where that would be very nice.

@deroneriksson  With recent bugfix in this PR, this feature can be turned on via MLContext as well:

```python
import numpy as np
from sklearn import datasets
from systemml.mllearn import LinearRegression
# Load the diabetes dataset
diabetes = datasets.load_diabetes()
# Use only one feature
diabetes_X = diabetes.data[:, np.newaxis, 2]
# Split the data into training/testing sets
X_train = diabetes_X[:-20]
X_test = diabetes_X[-20:]
# Split the targets into training/testing sets
y_train = diabetes.target[:-20]
y_test = diabetes.target[-20:]
# Create linear regression object
regr = LinearRegression(spark, fit_intercept=True, C=float("inf"), solver='direct-solve').setStatistics(True).setConfigProperty("systemml.stats.finegrained", "true")
# Train the model using the training sets
regr.fit(X_train, y_train)
```

This outputs:
```bash
SystemML Statistics:
Total elapsed time:             0.060 sec.
Total compilation time:         0.000 sec.
Total execution time:           0.060 sec.
Number of compiled Spark inst:  2.
Number of executed Spark inst:  2.
Cache hits (Mem, WB, FS, HDFS): 26/0/0/0.
Cache writes (WB, FS, HDFS):    1/0/0.
Cache times (ACQr/m, RLS, EXP): 0.000/0.000/0.001/0.000 sec.
HOP DAGs recompiled (PRED, SB): 0/0.
HOP DAGs recompile time:        0.000 sec.
Spark ctx create time (lazy):   0.000 sec.
Spark trans counts (par,bc,col):0/0/0.
Spark trans times (par,bc,col): 0.000/0.000/0.000 secs.
Total JIT compile time:         11.626 sec.
Total JVM GC count:             6.
Total JVM GC time:              0.219 sec.
Heavy hitter instructions:
  #  Instruction               Time(s)  Count  Misc Timers
  1  solve [148:0-148:0]         0.027      1  aqmd[0.000s,1]
  2  tsmm [137:4-137:13]         0.008      1  rlsi[0.000s,1], aqmd[0.000s,1], aqrd[0.000s,1]
  3  uak+ [161:10-161:10]        0.007      1  aqrd[0.000s,1], rlsi[0.000s,1]
  4  ba+* [138:4-138:13]         0.005      1  aqmd[0.000s,1], aqrd[0.000s,2], rlsi[0.000s,2]
  5  rand [89:0-89:0]            0.004      1  aqmd[0.000s,1]
  6  * [133:9-133:24]            0.002      1  aqmd[0.000s,1], aqrd[0.000s,1], rlsi[0.000s,1]
  7  r' [138:4-138:13]           0.001      2  aqmd[0.000s,2], aqrd[0.000s,2], rlsi[0.000s,2]
  8  append [97:4-97:4]          0.001      1  rlswr[0.000s,1], aqmd[0.000s,1], rlsev[0.000s,0], aqrd[0.000s,2], rlsi[0.000s,2]
  9  + [144:4-144:21]            0.001      1  aqmd[0.000s,1], aqrd[0.000s,2], rlsi[0.000s,2]
 10  leftIndex [104:4-104:26]    0.001      1  aqmd[0.000s,1], rlsi[0.000s,1], aqrd[0.000s,1]
```

`aqrd` and `aqmd` refers to dense input and outputs respectively. Similarly, `aqrs` and `aqms` refers to sparse input and outputs. It can also show both:
```bash
1  leftIndex [106:4-106:42]                                                       141.928   28552  aqrs[0.024s,23165], rls[0.066s,57104], csrlix[116.652s,22649], s2d[9.297s,258], aqrd[14.097s,33939], lixcp[1.410s,5903]
```

For custom code path, please see the [comment](https://github.com/niketanpansare/systemml/blob/b7ed58b4338f6448a3dd39c3778fc96a09e3c861/src/main/java/org/apache/sysml/runtime/instructions/cp/CPInstruction.java#L56). 

Thanks @deroneriksson for LGTM. I will hold off on merging this PR for 24 hours to give other committers an opportunity to provide feedback. After that, I will merge :)
Thanks @niketanpansare.

Refer to this link for build results (access rights to CI server needed): 
https://sparktc.ibmcloud.com/jenkins/job/SystemML-PullRequestBuilder/1787/

List of updates:
```
Shrink lite.xml size by over 50%.
Add MRJobConfiguration.USE_BINARYBLOCK_SERIALIZATION check.
Switch isLite/remotePar checks in InfrastructureAnalyzer.
Update BuildLite IO to use try-with-resources.
Remove commented code in BuildLite.
Switch displayMatrix to use DataConverter.
Update LiteCheck isLite to use try-with-resources.
Cache isLite results for performance.
Add default log4j.properties to root of artifact.
Add EventCounter class to lite artifact.
Exclude lite jar from python artifact if built at same time.
Generate entire dependencySets section from BuildLite.
Automatically update lite.xml dependencySets if lite.xml is found.
Allow commons-math3 option for all or only required classes.
Switch BuildLiteExecution output to utilize log4j.
```

Note that I tried switching to `MRJobConfiguration.addBinaryBlockSerializationFramework(_rJob)` but with this minimal lite jar I saw `Could not find a serializer for the Key class: 'org.apache.sysml.runtime.matrix.data.MatrixIndexes'`, so I kept the existing `MRConfigurationNames.IO_SERIALIZATIONS` call within the `USE_BINARYBLOCK_SERIALIZATION` check.

By handling the lite.xml differently for commons-logging and commons-math3, I was able to shrink the size of lite.xml by over 50%. WRT switching to calling BuildLiteExecution from the lite profile, I would say artifact maintentance would become very difficult (WRT issues such as licensing, included files, etc) since it would mean going from essentially our project's standard maven assembly technique for building our verified artifacts to a fairly convoluted programmatic technique. I think the lite.xml file used with the maven-assembly-plugin helps standardize how the artifact is built, which makes our release validation process easier. A side benefit of decoupling the actual BuildLiteExecution execution from the lite profile means that the artifact takes a few seconds to build rather than a few minutes.

```
spark-submit --master=spark://rr-ram4.softlayer.com:7077 --conf spark.executor.memory=120g --conf spark.driver.memory=80g /home/iyounus/git/incubator-systemml/target/SystemML.jar -f /home/iyounus/git/incubator-systemml/scripts/staging/tSNE.dml -exec hybrid_spark -nvargs INPUT=data/mnist_train_no_labels.csv OUT=data/P.csv
```

In my opinion, "SPARK" and "HADOOP" are not useless for the user. One of the first things I typically say to a user running into an issue in "HYBRID_SPARK" mode is to try running in "SPARK" mode, which typically reveals various issues that are useful when debugging. Usually in order to set this in the past (via MLContext in a notebook) I have had to instruct the user to perform a hack by setting DMLScript.rtplatform = DMLScript.RUNTIME_PLATFORM.SPARK.
@iyounus Have you had a chance to look at issues specified by @mboehm7?

cc @deroneriksson . To my understanding I used a lite random matrices as inputs and provided some general parameter values, and wrote output to the output matrix for different modes(probability dist.). Is it the way to do this?. I'll correct the syntax errors in the next commit.

Thank you @j143. I think this is a good start so far (definitely fix syntax errors in next commit).

I'm not a data scientist so I'd say I'm not really a good judge of the exact nature of how the algorithm should be tested. I would have a look at `org.apache.sysml.test.integration.functions.codegen.AlgorithmGLM` and possibly replicate some of the same types of tests but run through MLContext, and it looks like you are indeed following that approach. From a software engineering perspective, I would examine the GLM.dml script and look to execute as many of the code paths resulting from the various conditions as possible. Perhaps @mboehm7 could provide further assistance.

Please also add the MLContextGLMTest class to src/test_suites/java/org/apache/sysml/test/integration/mlcontext/algorithms/ZPackageSuite.java.
Also note that the input parameters (such as "$dfam") will probably need "$" prepended to their names when being set through the MLContext API.
Thanks for reviewing @dusenberrymw. I renamed the test classes in the first commit and then updated the majority of the content in the second commit to preserve the history for these files.

Please do the following on your cluster:
1. Increase the ulimit on **all nodes**: `ulimit -n 65000`
2. `wget https://raw.githubusercontent.com/apache/systemml/master/conf/SystemML-config.xml.template`, `mv SystemML-config.xml.template SystemML-config.xml` and set `systemml.stats.finegrained` in that file to `true`.
3. Rerun your command and send statistics :)
Thanks @dusenberrymw. I'll merge after successful completion of tests.
@mboehm7 When you have time, please let me know what you think of the latest updates.

Hi @mboehm7 !
1. May be we can consider one more thing here, Imran Younus has tried to implement the distributed svd() with the help of local svd( ) already in PR #273 , (which I believe is robust w/ acceptable accuracy, isn't it?) of the latest algorithm in the literature. 

2. It may be worthy of taking into account that too(?). Please give me, 20-25 hrs on studying the current literature that the distributed algorithm is using at its backbone, to understand whether the algorithm have any conflicts with distribution calculations at the matrix block level.

3. Will it helps us understand when implementing the other functions, internal or external implementation that perform well in our setting?. As @nakul02 pointed out, we try the above implementations for POV of GPU too. 

Please provide any thoughts. Thanks. :smile:
LGTM Thanks @asurve

Both positive and negative zero are considered zero - our sparse representation would never store a negative zero as a non-zero. Accordingly, you can leave the code for sparse outputs unchanged (note that 0.0==-0.0 and hence the existing check value != 0.0 already discards -0.0 as well)

I've rebased it - https://github.com/nakul02/systemml/tree/svd
Here on out, you can rebase it yourself. Clone my svd branch on to the clone/fork of the systemml repository and rebase that with master.
If you run into issues doing that, please let me know.
